Linguistic covariation and coherence

Introduction

Overview

  1. Covariation and coherence
  2. Methods and connections
  3. Hopes

Covariation and coherence

How do linguistic variables work together?

How do speakers cluster w.r.t. multiple variables?

Do speakers pattern in the same way across the lifespan?

Are styles, lects, registers, persona, characterised
by collections of covarying variables?

This session

Quantitative methods for exploring covariation of linguistic variables.

Garden paths

  • Clustering methods can find clusters in random data
  • Epistemic issues in research applying machine learning are relevant.
  • Fears of a new replication crisis (see, e.g., Kapoor and Narayanan 2022)
  • Careful application is necessary!
  • Value in focusing on methods.

Methods

PCA

  • PCA: Principal Component Analysis
  • Described by Wilson Black and Sheard (11:45)
  • Finds (usually interpretable) structure in continuous multivariate data.
  • e.g.: Patterns in vocalic formant readings.
    • Do certain vowels tend to move together?
    • Do speakers cluster with respect to covarying vowels?

PCA and friends

  • Key question: what do we put in to PCA?
    • Raw data.
    • Model predictions (incl. CCA: Constrained Correspondence Analysis)
      • i.e., the variation explained by identified predictors
      • see Hurring (12:15) and Walker (1:45).
    • Random intercepts or residuals (e.g. Brand et al. 2021)
      • i.e., the variation not explained by identified predictors.
      • see Hurring (12:15). Wilson Black and Sheard (11:45).
  • What do we do after PCA?
    • e.g.: compare sizes groups in ‘PC space’ (Beaman and Sering 2022)

MDS

  • Pairwise differences -> a multidimensial space.
    • e.g. perceptual judgments of similarity.
    • e.g. difference measures derived from production data.
  • Like PCA: speakers can be clustered in a continuous space.
  • Additional methods are needed to explain the dimensions.
  • Sheard et al. (11:15) use MDS to explore the factors driving perceptual similarity judgmenets.
  • Key question: can listeners hear the clusters picked out by PCA applied to production data.

Tree methods

  • Clustering algorithms can (often) be represented by trees.
  • Divisive clustering starts with one cluster, then successively breaks off objects into new clusters.
  • These ‘breaks’ form a tree.

Tree methods (cont.)

  • Tree-based clustering is very flexible.
  • Choosing the number of clusters can be difficult
  • Travis and Qiao (2:15) interpret classification trees via social categories held back from their clustering model.
  • Upshot: a new way of getting at the issue of class vs ethnic classifications.
  • Other tree methods split by a single variable.
  • Sheard et al. (11:15) use regression trees to interpret MDS results.

Hopes

Hopes

  • Increased sharing of methods.
  • Cross pollination.
  • Emergence of new methods.
  • Increased use of open science practices.
